review.title: Synthesizing Robust Plans under Incomplete Domain Models
review.abstract: Most current planners assume complete domain models and focus on generating correct plans. Unfortunately, domain modeling is a laborious and error-prone task. While domain experts cannot guarantee completeness, often they are able to circumscribe the incompleteness of the model by providing annotations as to which parts of the domain model may be incomplete. In such cases, the goal should be to generate plans that are robust with respect to any known incompleteness of the domain. In this paper, we first introduce annotations expressing the knowledge of the domain incompleteness, and formalize the notion of plan robustness with respect to an incomplete domain model. We then propose an approach to compiling the problem of finding robust plans to the conformant probabilistic planning problem. We present experimental results with Probabilistic-FF, a state-of-the-art planner, showing the promise of our approach.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Robust Plans under Incomplete Domain Models

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Significant advances have been made in the scaling of plan synthesis techniques in recent years. We now have a technology that generates plans with hundreds of actions, but all of this work makes one crucial assumption - that a complete model of the domain is defined in advance. While there are areas where knowledge engineering makes such detailed models necessary and feasible (e.g., mission planning domains in NASA and factory planning), it is increasingly recognized (Hoffmann, Weber and Kraft 2007) that there are also many scenarios where insisting on correct and complete models renders current planning technology useless. What we need is a planning technology that can handle partially specified domain models and still generate plans that are "robust" in the sense that they are successful in the real and complete world.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: Although there has been some work to reduce the "errors" in plan execution (e.g. work on the non-deterministic planning error plans (Jensen, Veloso and Bryant 2004)), it is based on the context of stochastic / non-deterministic actions and not on incompletely specified ones. Semantics of the possible preconditions / effects in our incomplete domain models are fundamentally different from non-deterministic and stochastic effects. Otherwise, if the effects of the pick-up action are stochastical, trying out the same pick-up action multiple times in the Gripper example above increases the chances of success. Garland & Lesh (2002) share the same goal of generating robust plans among incomplete domain models.

sections.heading: 6. Experimental Results
sections.text: We tested the compilation with Probabilistic-FF (PFF), a state-of-the-art planner, on a number of domains in the International Planning Competition.We will first discuss the results of the variants of logistics and satellite domains, in which the incompleteness of the domains is consciously modelled on the planning phase. We will then describe the second experimental settings, in which we randomly introduce the incompleteness of the generated plans into the IPC domains, and discuss the feasibility of our approach in this seting.3Domains with deliberate incompleteness Logistics: In this domain, each of the two cities C1 and C2 has an airport and an inland area. Transport between the two distant cities can only be done by two planes A1 and A2.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we emphasized the need to synthesize robust plans under incomplete domain models; we introduced notes expressing domain incompleteness; formalized the notion of planning certainty; and demonstrated an approach to transferring the problem of creating robust plans to compliant probabilistic planning; we presented empirical results that reflect the promise of our approach; and for future work, we developed a planning approach that incorporates the incompleteness notes directly into the search and compares them with our current method of creation; we also plan to consider the issue of robustness of a given plan subject to a projected cost limit.
